justification: The MCAS assesses five evaluative dimensions of condom use attitudes: perceptions of condoms as reliable and effective, sexual pleasure associated with condom use, stigma related to condom use, embarrassment about negotiating condom use, and embarrassment about purchasing condoms. This comprehensive scale is used to evaluate various aspects of attitudes toward condoms.

This scale measures prevention focus and promotion focus in sexuality. It includes three items for prevention focus and six items for promotion focus, providing a reliable measure of how individuals orient their sexual behavior towards security or pleasure.

measured_by: Perceived Risk of HIV Scale developed by Napper and colleagues (2012)
justification: Four items from the original Perceived Risk of HIV Scale were used to measure perceived chances, vulnerability, and salience of risk concerning HIV infection. The scale was adapted based on high factor loadings from a Portuguese validation study.

measured_by: Big-Five Inventory-10 by Rammstedt and John (2007)
justification: The 10-item short version of the Big Five Inventory assesses personality traits including extraversion, agreeableness, conscientiousness, neuroticism, and openness. The scale is brief yet effective in capturing the essential dimensions of personality.
